abstract: Comcast said it will develop a bill of rights for the use of peer-to-peer file-sharing programs. The announcement was scorned on the blogs, but Comcast is actually promising to give the net neutrality advocates much of what they have demanded.
snippet: Comcast said it will develop a bill of rights for the use of peer-to-peer file-sharing programs. The announcement was scorned on the blogs, but Comcast is actually promising to give the net neutrality advocates much of what they have demanded.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday afternoon, Comcast put out a vague, jargon-filled news release about working to create a “Bill of Rights and Responsibilities” for users of peer-to-peer file-sharing software. The release has prompted no shortage of criticism on blogs.

abstract: Richard Sandomir reports: Comcast is turning to Mike Weisman, a 35-year veteran of sports producing, to “improve the quality of its national sports networks — the Golf Channel and Versus — and its eight regional sports networks and two channels devoted to the Mountain West Conference and southeastern regional sports.”
lead_paragraph: Richard Sandomir reports: Comcast is turning to Mike Weisman, a 35-year veteran of sports producing, to “improve the quality of its national sports networks — the Golf Channel and Versus — and its eight regional sports networks and two channels devoted to the Mountain West Conference and southeastern regional sports.”

headline.main: Comcast Hires Consultant to Improve Sports Channels
